G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody and visitation under Massachusetts General Laws (“G.L.”) c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and c. 209C, § 20, which authorize modification of custody and parenting orders when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred, and where modification serves the best interests of the children.

c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody and visitation under Massachusetts General Laws (“G.L.”) c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and c. 209C, § 20, which authorize modification of custody and parenting orders when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred, and where modification serves the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a custody and parenting judgment may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification would be in the children’s best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a custody and parenting judgment may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification would be in the children’s best interests.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The authority of the Court to revise custody orders to reflect the children’s best interests is further supported by G.L. c. 208, § 31; G.L. c. 208, § 1A; G.L. c. 215, § 6, and related case law.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 1A.proposition: The authority of the Court to revise custody orders to reflect the children’s best interests is further supported by G.L. c. 208, § 31; G.L. c. 208, § 1A; G.L. c. 215, § 6, and related case law.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (2.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody determinations in Massachusetts.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion strongly affirms that the best interests of the child is the controlling standard in custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and describes it as the long-standing principle in Massachusetts custody law. However, it expressly contrasts that standard with the different “substantial change in circumstances” standard for modification proceedings and does not say that best interests governs *all* custody determinations in every statutory context (e.g., modifications under § 20). Thus it supports the centrality of the best-interests standard in initial custody awards, but not the universal “all custody determinations” formulation claimed.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’).”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody determinations in Massachusetts.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not say that the best interests standard governs *all* custody determinations; instead, it applies that standard specifically in the context of modification of prior custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and removal under § 30. The court quotes the statute requiring that a modification be “necessary in the best interests of the children” and describes best interests as the “governing principle” in custody-transfer cases, but it does not purport to state a universal rule for every type of custody determination in Massachusetts. Using this case as authority for the broad "all custody determinations" proposition overstates what it actually holds.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’). The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations.”}

*Herb v. Herb*, 8 Mass. App. Ct. 419 (19.proposition: The Court must examine current circumstances, not merely conditions at the time of the original judgment.
*Herb v. Herb*, 8 Mass. App. Ct. 419 (19.case_name: N. J. Gendron Lumber Co. v. Great Northern Homes, Inc.
*Herb v. Herb*, 8 Mass. App. Ct. 419 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract/guaranty and commercial bribery case; it does not involve modification of a prior judgment or any requirement that a court look to current versus past circumstances in that context. Nothing in the reasoning discusses temporal focus for revising or enforcing an earlier judgment, so it does not establish or affirm the claimed proposition. The citation would therefore be inaccurate for that legal point.
*Herb v. Herb*, 8 Mass. App. Ct. 419 (19.relevant_excerpt: Second, the jury were entitled to infer from the circumstances under which Rule gave the guaranty, i.e., at Gendron’s insistence and at the very time when the note device was first employed, that the guaranty covered that part of Great Northern’s debt evidenced by the note, as well as Great Northern’s open account with Gendron. Third, the scope of the guaranty would properly be viewed in light of the construction which the parties adopted and acted upon.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: A breakdown in co-parenting communication or cooperation may constitute the requisite material change for modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal divorce/custody decision, not a post-judgment modification case. While the court repeatedly emphasizes the parties’ severe antagonism, inability to communicate, and disagreement on child rearing, it does so to justify the *original* allocation of custody, visitation, and property, not to find a material change warranting modification of an existing order. Thus, it does not address or establish any rule about breakdowns in co-parenting communication constituting a material change for modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt:
The judge could, accordingly, consider the parties’ respective financial resources, as well as their “difficulty in communicating” and their total inability to “cooperate with each other” and “agree on child rearing,” and reasonably conclude that the optimum arrangement for the future would be to preclude all personal interaction and financial transactions between the parties.
...
Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing... an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.proposition: A breakdown in co-parenting communication or cooperation may constitute the requisite material change for modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on the best interests standard where parents share joint legal and physical custody. It does not discuss modification standards in terms of a ‘material change in circumstances,’ nor does it address whether a breakdown in co‑parenting communication or cooperation can constitute such a change. The opinion’s discussion of joint custody emphasizes the need for cooperation but does not tie communication breakdowns to the legal threshold for modification, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31, such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children. … Shared physical custody in particular carries with it substantial obligation for cooperation between the parents.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Court gives primacy to the children’s welfare over parental convenience or preferences.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the ‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’ and that removal must be in the child’s best interests, even while considering the custodial parent’s interests. It further notes that the detriment to the noncustodial parent’s visitation rights ‘cannot be controlling,’ confirming that children’s welfare is primary over parental preferences or convenience.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the “real advantage” test is grounded on the “realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.” Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, “[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.” Id. at 54.
...
The fact that visitation by the noncustodial parent will be changed to his or her disadvantage cannot be controlling.

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.proposition: Persistent disparagement or manipulation of the children’s perception of a parent can justify modification, as such behavior undermines the cooperative parenting required for shared legal custody.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.support_reasoning: The case is a care-and-protection termination-type proceeding focused on physical abuse, parental unfitness, evidentiary standards, and the permissibility of drawing adverse inferences from parents’ failure to testify. It does not address shared legal custody, cooperative parenting, or parental disparagement/manipulation of a child’s perception of the other parent as a basis for modifying custody. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.relevant_excerpt: A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children... The court is permitted to assess prognostic evidence derived from prior patterns of parental neglect or misconduct in determining future fitness and the likelihood of harm to the child.

*Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 403.proposition: Persistent disparagement or manipulation of the children’s perception of a parent can justify modification, as such behavior undermines the cooperative parenting required for shared legal custody.
*Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 403.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss why joint custody is inappropriate where parents cannot cooperate in child rearing, but it does not address persistent disparagement or manipulation of the children’s perception of a parent as a basis for modification. There is no language about a parent undermining the children’s relationship with the other parent or using disparagement as a reason to change custody. The case is focused on initial custody determination and the need for parental cooperation for joint custody, not on post‑judgment modification based on disparaging conduct.
*Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 403.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’… ‘[J]oint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The emotional strain and psychosomatic symptoms experienced by the children, coupled with communication breakdown and disparagement, demonstrate that the existing shared legal custody is no longer viable or consistent with their best interests.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The case concerns the need for explicit findings about the effects of domestic violence when awarding or continuing custody, especially shared custody where a 209A order exists. It does not discuss emotional strain, psychosomatic symptoms, communication breakdown, or disparagement between parents as grounds for finding that an existing shared legal custody arrangement is no longer viable. The holding is procedural (requiring detailed findings on domestic violence and its impact) rather than a substantive ruling that such relational and emotional factors render shared legal custody inconsistent with the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ A G. L. c. 209A order was outstanding in this case, and the judge made no explicit findings regarding the effect of shared custody on the child.”

*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (19.proposition: The emotional strain and psychosomatic symptoms experienced by the children, coupled with communication breakdown and disparagement, demonstrate that the existing shared legal custody is no longer viable or consistent with their best interests.
*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns termination of parental rights and fitness for adoption, not modification or viability of a shared legal custody arrangement between parents. While the opinion notes the children’s extreme anxiety and emotional distress around visits, it uses those facts to support a finding of parental unfitness and the detriment of returning the children to their parents, not to conclude that an existing shared legal custody order is no longer viable. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about shared legal custody becoming inconsistent with the children’s best interests.
*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Here, there was evidence that the children exhibited extreme anxiety before and after visits with their mother. Following one visit, John physically abused himself and Quentin exhibited aggressive behavior. Prior to another visit, Ellen ‘cried, appeared to be scared, agitated, and fearful, and told [the department case worker] to tell [her mother] that she was sick. The next week, [Ellen] again refused to visit her mother . . . yelling, ‘You can’t make me go.’ Eventually, the judge suspended the weekly visits.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that where one parent fails to communicate or acts in ways that undermine the other parent’s relationship with the children, shared legal custody should not continue.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion is about relocation and statutory rights of an unmarried, sole legal custodian under G.L. c. 209C, not about when shared legal custody should be terminated. It does not discuss joint or shared legal custody, parental failure to communicate, or one parent undermining the other’s relationship as a basis for ending shared legal custody. The case therefore does not establish or affirm the proposition claimed and is being used out of context for that proposition.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. ... As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is 'free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].' ... The paternity statute ... gives primacy to the stability of a nonmarital child by vesting sole legal parentage in the mother unless and until there has issued a legal determination of paternity or a voluntary acknowledgment of paternity."

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that where one parent fails to communicate or acts in ways that undermine the other parent’s relationship with the children, shared legal custody should not continue.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that a parent’s ability to separate their own needs from the child’s and not compromise the child’s relationship with the other parent is a relevant factor in custody determinations, citing Hernandez v. Branciforte. The court affirms an award of sole legal custody and a suspension of the father’s contact based, in part, on findings that he disparaged the mother to the child and damaged the mother–child relationship. This aligns with the proposition that where a parent undermines the other parent’s relationship or cannot communicate appropriately, shared legal custody should not continue.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: As the judge correctly noted, “[a] determination of whether a parent is able to separate his or her needs and interests from those of the minor children and whether a parent’s actions will compromise the minor children’s relationship with the other parent are relevant factors in determining custody.” See Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 212, 220-221 (2002). Finally, the judge explained why neither unsupervised nor supervised visitation between the father and the child was feasible.... The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that ... in his interactions with the child, [the father] had damaged the mother’s relationship with the child.
